entry.value: This page features Rapid's page event features.

Rapid has a number of different events that can be activated on a page. These events are split into page load, resume, and reuse. To begin we will be talking about the page load event, as it is the easiest of the three to begin with.

The page load event has the capability of activating features whenever the page is loaded, or refreshed. This can be especially useful in a multitude of different situations, with the best example being pre-populating information on a page either through Rapid or a database. In our first example we have provided a multitude of different controls that are populated as soon as the page loads. Clicking on the 'Empty fields' button will clear these controls of any information that has been added to them.

As page load events have the same action capabilities as other events the example above is just a simple example on how to use them. Moving on we are now going to go into detail on how reusable events work. In order to discuss the reusable page event in detail we must first cover the group action.

The group action is used for combining actions together in a single step. This is especially useful if you have a lot of actions that take place in the page properties, are able to bundle them together, and want them to occur at the same time. As group actions are capable of doing this it is a very niche action, but can find itself used in a multitude of ways.

With the group action covered we can cover page reusable events. Reusable events will never trigger by themselves, and will only activate upon being called elsewhere in your Rapid application. By having group actions in a reusable event it becomes much easier to manage and call what you need at the right time. By calling on the reusable page event in an existing action you can activate those groups at any time in your application. Below is a simple example on reusable events and a group action.

Before moving on to the last page event it is worth mentioning that there is a dedicated event action. This event action has the capability of firing off any event on the page it is used. This can be used to trigger events again on the page, without having to carry out that specific action. The example below is a single button that will generate or empty the above data based on whether data is present or not.

The last page event we are going to cover is the resume event. This event functions with mobile apps in mind, using Rapid's mobile client. For most apps this event will go unused, however for apps specifically for use through Rapid's mobile client then this event becomes a vital asset in your application.

When on an app on a mobile or tablet device it is possible to leave the app using that device's respective home button. When doing this certain events in the Rapid mobile client are paused, delayed, or stopped. Examples of stopped functionality upon exit include GPS tracking and timer events. In order to not use resources that are no longer needed this functionality is switched off. Upon resuming the the mobile client the page load events will not be fired, but the page resume events will.

The resume event can be used to switch deactivated settings back on, such as the GPS settings and timers. As timed events are ceased they will need to be re-initiated in the resume event. An example of this is an auto-save function. Manual resizing of the app is also something that can be included in the page resume, in the event that the orientation is changed and has not been picked up. When viewing Rapid apps from a browser or desktop device the load events will fire first, followed by the resume events. In our example below we will set the resume event to occur after a set interval has passed.

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C83_","text":"As shown when the page loads, the controls are populated with some pre-made data. This can be incredibly
useful to pull a user's existing details from a database to save time, or to alter this data for another
submission. You may notice that when you regenerate the data using the button at the top of the page
that we are actually using an existing event. Any event on the same page can be recalled by other
controls on the page!","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C139_","text":"Reusable events are quite niche, along with the group action, however it is capable of performing quite
powerful functions in an organised manner. The immediate benefit of combining group actions and reusable
page actions is the space it saves on the page properties. By calling these as an existing action it allows
the page in the Rapid designer to load a lot faster. As reuse events can be triggered at any point in
your Rapid application it can be very handy for testing various functionality.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C295_","text":"Using the event action will trigger all of the associated actions on that particular event. Generally
the event action is used to fire off page load events without having to explicitly reload the page.
It can also be used to fire off a button's click event after a certain action has occurred on the page.
Whilst there are other ways of doing the latter, both are viable circumstances to use the event action.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C265_","text":"As the example shows, when not viewed using Rapid's mobile client, the grid will populate with information when the interval timer has elapsed, in this case 5 seconds. In order to have this timed event we have used the timer action. The timer action allows you to define an interval and the action will take place after the time has elapsed. If this demo application is viewed through Rapid's mobile client then the resume event will fire whenever the app is cancelled out of through the home button, or through the device's lock feature. To try the Rapid mobile client out for yourself a link has been provided on this hint and clicking it will lead you to the Rapid mobile client in the Google Play store.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C83_","text":"As shown when the page loads, the controls are populated with some pre-made data. This can be incredibly
useful to pull a user's existing details from a database to save time, or to alter this data for another
submission. You may notice that when you regenerate the data using the button at the top of the page
that we are actually using an existing event. Any event on the same page can be recalled by other
controls on the page!","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C139_","text":"Reusable events are quite niche, along with the group action, however it is capable of performing quite
powerful functions in an organised manner. The immediate benefit of combining group actions and reusable
page actions is the space it saves on the page properties. By calling these as an existing action it allows
the page in the Rapid designer to load a lot faster. As reuse events can be triggered at any point in
your Rapid application it can be very handy for testing various functionality.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C295_","text":"Using the event action will trigger all of the associated actions on that particular event. Generally
the event action is used to fire off page load events without having to explicitly reload the page.
It can also be used to fire off a button's click event after a certain action has occurred on the page.
Whilst there are other ways of doing the latter, both are viable circumstances to use the event action.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P10_C265_","text":"As the example shows, when not viewed using Rapid's mobile client, the grid will populate with information when the interval timer has elapsed, in this case 5 seconds. In order to have this timed event we have used the timer action. The timer action allows you to define an interval and the action will take place after the time has elapsed. If this demo application is viewed through Rapid's mobile client then the resume event will fire whenever the app is cancelled out of through the home button, or through the device's lock feature. To try the Rapid mobile client out for yourself a link has been provided on this hint and clicking it will lead you to the Rapid mobile client in the Google Play store.","type":"hover"}]}

query.SQL: select forename, surname, birthday, gender from people where id > 3 and id < 9 or id > 99 and id < 105 order by RANDOM()

page.htmlBody:
This page features Rapid's page event features.

Rapid has a number of different events that can be activated on a page. These events are split into page load, resume, and reuse. To begin we will be talking about the page load event, as it is the easiest of the three to begin with.The page load event has the capability of activating features whenever the page is loaded, or refreshed. This can be especially useful in a multitude of different situations, with the best example being pre-populating information on a page either through Rapid or a database. In our first example we have provided a multitude of different controls that are populated as soon as the page loads. Clicking on the 'Empty fields' button will clear these controls of any information that has been added to them.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
As page load events have the same action capabilities as other events the example above is just a simple example on how to use them. Moving on we are now going to go into detail on how reusable events work. In order to discuss the reusable page event in detail we must first cover the group action.The group action is used for combining actions together in a single step. This is especially useful if you have a lot of actions that take place in the page properties, are able to bundle them together, and want them to occur at the same time. As group actions are capable of doing this it is a very niche action, but can find itself used in a multitude of ways.With the group action covered we can cover page reusable events. Reusable events will never trigger by themselves, and will only activate upon being called elsewhere in your Rapid application. By having group actions in a reusable event it becomes much easier to manage and call what you need at the right time. By calling on the reusable page event in an existing action you can activate those groups at any time in your application. Below is a simple example on reusable events and a group action.
Name
Birthday
Gender
Favourite weekdays
Before moving on to the last page event it is worth mentioning that there is a dedicated event action. This event action has the capability of firing off any event on the page it is used. This can be used to trigger events again on the page, without having to carry out that specific action. The example below is a single button that will generate or empty the above data based on whether data is present or not.
The last page event we are going to cover is the resume event. This event functions with mobile apps in mind, using Rapid's mobile client. For most apps this event will go unused, however for apps specifically for use through Rapid's mobile client then this event becomes a vital asset in your application.When on an app on a mobile or tablet device it is possible to leave the app using that device's respective home button. When doing this certain events in the Rapid mobile client are paused, delayed, or stopped. Examples of stopped functionality upon exit include GPS tracking and timer events. In order to not use resources that are no longer needed this functionality is switched off. Upon resuming the the mobile client the page load events will not be fired, but the page resume events will.The resume event can be used to switch deactivated settings back on, such as the GPS settings and timers. As timed events are ceased they will need to be re-initiated in the resume event. An example of this is an auto-save function. Manual resizing of the app is also something that can be included in the page resume, in the event that the orientation is changed and has not been picked up. When viewing Rapid apps from a browser or desktop device the load events will fire first, followed by the resume events. In our example below we will set the resume event to occur after a set interval has passed.
ForenameSurnameDate of birthGender
page.name: 13_pageEvents

rolesHtml.html:
This page features Rapid's page event features.

Rapid has a number of different events that can be activated on a page. These events are split into page load, resume, and reuse. To begin we will be talking about the page load event, as it is the easiest of the three to begin with.The page load event has the capability of activating features whenever the page is loaded, or refreshed. First name

Gender
As page load events have the same action capabilities as other events the example above is just a simple example on how to use them. Moving on we are now going to go into detail on how reusable events work. In order to discuss the reusable page event in detail we must first cover the group action.The group action is used for combining actions together in a single step. Before moving on to the last page event it is worth mentioning that there is a dedicated event action. This event action has the capability of firing off any event on the page it is used. The example below is a single button that will generate or empty the above data based on whether data is present or not.
The last page event we are going to cover is the resume event. This event functions with mobile apps in mind, using Rapid's mobile client. page.title: Page events
